receiver: Chief Executive Officer South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust

concern_responses.concern: The NHS Pathways system does not differentiate between types, severity, or specific drugs/chemicals involved in overdoses, nor does it consider the amount ingested, timing of ingestion, or patient's weight, which can all impact the urgency of care required.

action_phrases: Will align the NHS Pathways system if national guidance or standards are amended to impact ambulance categorisation or disposition for toxic substances.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive Officer South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Will support a workstream exploring use of AI to ambiently listen to 999 calls to highlight rare or unique risks, including [redacted] overdose, earlier.

concern_responses.concern: The Pathways system does not account for the time-sensitive nature of certain ingestions, such as [REDACTED], where effective treatment must be administered before cardiac arrest, and does not assign a higher response category when this is known.

action_phrases: Will continue urgent remote clinical assessment for overdose cases not automatically resulting in Category 1 or 2 response, upgrading if clinical view supports it.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive Officer South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Will continue to follow procedures requiring further clinical intervention within 30 minutes of overdose declaration or automatic upgrade if not completed within 40 minutes.

concern_responses.concern: Clinicians on ambulances within South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust do not carry Methylene Blue, the antidote to [REDACTED] ingestion, as it is not within national guidance, resulting in treatment only being available at acute hospitals, which may be too late for some patients.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Chief Executive Officer South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Will continue to review medication formulary and monitor national guidance regarding methylene blue, modifying protocols if appropriate.

concern_responses.concern: There is a risk that taxi drivers may leave passengers in unsafe locations, as evidenced by the driver stating he would do nothing differently in similar circumstances.

action_phrases: Updated the DR18 Driver Information & Advice document with new sections and strengthened guidance, and issued it to all drivers on 3rd January 2025.

concern_responses.concern: Kingkabs did not contact the police in this incident, despite the firm's stated usual practice to do so in such circumstances.

action_phrases: Documented new Driver Incident Procedures in CC002 Call Centre Procedures and sent the updated document to all staff on 3rd January 2025.

concern_responses.concern: There is no evidence or documentation to corroborate that Kingkabs staff are being trained in the protocol of contacting the police in such situations.

action_phrases: Sent updated CC002 Call Centre Procedures document, including police contact protocol, to all staff on 3rd January 2025.

receiver: Chief Executive, West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust
Chief Executive, Suffolk and North East Essex Integrated Care Board

concern_responses.concern: Neither the NICE guideline [NG225] nor the SNEE/SCC policy were applied in relation to the care and treatment extended to Erin in the West Suffolk Hospital Emergency Department during her attendance over the period 31 December 2022 to 1 January 2023.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive, West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Updated Mental Health – supporting patients with their mental health (PP459) policy in August 2024 to include new section 5.3 on emergency admissions and triage.

concern_responses.concern: The failure to apply this guidance and policy resulted in a missed opportunity for mental health services to engage early with a vulnerable child who had presented to the Emergency Department having undertaken an act which she described as an overdose.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive, West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Extended and adapted Manchester Triage system for under 18s, including automatic MHLT referral triggers for overdose, live on Ecare as of two weeks ago.

receiver: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust

concern_responses.concern: Laboratory staff did not phone through grossly elevated LFT results to clinical staff once obtained in the laboratory.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
action_phrases: RCOG will review the response from the Royal College of Pathologists and ensure it is communicated with members and included in relevant clinical guidance.
The need to agree local cut offs with clinicians will be emphasised in the next revision of the Communication of Critical and Unexpected Pathology Results document.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Once national guidance is available, UHBW will set up a task and finish group to implement new reference ranges for urgent reporting of LFTs in pregnancy across the Trust.
[no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: The Royal College of Pathologists’ guidelines for urgent reporting only require phoning results above 750 for ALT, 300 for bilirubin, and 354 for creatinine, and do not provide for different reporting levels for pregnant women.

action_phrases: The need to agree local cut offs with clinicians, including for pregnancy, will be emphasised in the next revision of the Communication of Critical and Unexpected Pathology Results document.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
action_phrases: RCOG will review the response from the Royal College of Pathologists and ensure it is communicated with members and included in relevant clinical guidance.
[no response]
[no response]

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: UHBW has written to the Royal College of Pathologists and Royal College of Obstetricians asking them to consider the development of national guidance on reference ranges for LFTs in pregnancy.

concern_responses.concern: Pregnancy specific conditions such as Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy can be potentially fatal at much lower levels of abnormal LFTs than those currently set by the Royal College of Pathologists.

action_phrases: NHS England supports the revision of the Royal College of Pathologists’ guidelines to incorporate different urgent reporting levels for results of tests taken during pregnancy.
The need to agree local cut offs with clinicians, which might include pregnancy, will be emphasised in the next revision of the Communication of Critical and Unexpected Pathology Results document.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
action_phrases: RCOG will review the response from the Royal College of Pathologists and ensure it is communicated with members and included in relevant clinical guidance.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: UHBW has written to the Royal College of Pathologists and Royal College of Obstetricians asking them to consider the development of national guidance on reference ranges for LFTs in pregnancy.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: There was a delay in diagnosing Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy and starting appropriate treatment as a result of the reporting thresholds and lack of communication of abnormal results.

action_phrases: NHS England has established Maternal Medicine Networks to improve specialist advice and care for women with acute medical problems before, during, and after pregnancy.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
action_phrases: RCOG will review the response from the Royal College of Pathologists and ensure it is communicated with members and included in relevant clinical guidance.
The need to agree local cut offs with clinicians will be emphasised in the next revision of the Communication of Critical and Unexpected Pathology Results document.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Once national guidance is available, UHBW will set up a task and finish group to implement new reference ranges for urgent reporting of LFTs in pregnancy across the Trust.
[no response]

receiver: The Chief Executive Officer of University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
The Chief Executive Officer of George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust

concern_responses.concern: Non-specialist medical staff may have varied understanding of the appropriate contacts and timing for engaging with specialist renal hospitals.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust
action_phrases: Display laminated quick reference guide with emergency contact numbers for renal services at UHCW across the Trust.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Outline current processes for GEH to contact specialist renal and virology teams in the guidelines.
Recommend all hospital switchboards, Emergency Departments and relevant personnel have a master copy of local specialist centre contact details.
Recommend all hospital switchboards, Emergency Departments and relevant personnel have a master copy of local specialist centre contact details.
[no response]
Share PFD reports and learning with Regional Medical Directors and clinical colleagues via the Regulation 28 Working Group.

concern_responses.concern: The specific patient information that non-specialist staff should provide to specialist renal hospitals may not always be clearly defined.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust
action_phrases: Guidelines illustrate sample collection requirements, actions for positive results, and telephone numbers to be used.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Guidelines and SLA set up a clear framework for communication, including timely investigation and treatment, and processes to document communication.
Advise that electronic information sharing in real-time should be the gold standard for information sharing.
Advise that electronic information sharing in real-time should be the gold standard for information sharing.
[no response]
Specialist Clinical Reference Group has developed service specifications that define standards of care for kidney transplantation and acute kidney injuries.

concern_responses.concern: Non-specialist staff may experience varying levels of awareness or accessibility to guidelines and protocols for treating kidney transplant patients, which could lead to a misunderstanding of the significance and urgency of the actions recommended by specialist renal hospitals.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust
action_phrases: Guidelines from UHCW will be available on the intranet once ratified and have been shared with all Directorates.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Guidelines have been cascaded within clinical teams and will be placed on the UHCW intranet after governance ratification.
Advise that the critical action is to contact the Specialist Centre if there is misunderstanding of urgency.
Advise that the critical action is to contact the Specialist Centre if there is misunderstanding of urgency.
[no response]
Share PFD reports and learning with Regional Medical Directors and clinical colleagues via the Regulation 28 Working Group.

concern_responses.concern: There may be some inconsistency across non-specialist hospitals and renal hospitals in understanding who is responsible for initiating patient transfers.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust
action_phrases: Consultant to consultant clinical conversations will take place if there is a requirement to transfer the patient to the renal centre.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: UHCW will be responsible to accept all renal patients admitted to GEH, and daily huddle at 11.30am highlights interhospital transfers.
Recommend that when a Specialist Team is managing care, they assume responsibility for recommending the best location for care delivery.
Recommend that when a Specialist Team is managing care, they assume responsibility for recommending the best location for care delivery.
[no response]
Share PFD reports and learning with Regional Medical Directors and clinical colleagues via the Regulation 28 Working Group.

concern_responses.concern: Considerations regarding whether patients should remain in non-specialist areas or be transferred may differ, potentially affecting consistency in care approaches.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust
action_phrases: Consultant to consultant referral process in place where decisions are made on location based on the patient's clinical need.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: SLA supports decision-making for patient location by ensuring face to face communication between senior medical staff from UHCW and GEH.
Recommend that the responsible Specialist Team is from the local specialist renal centre and liaise with other centres if necessary.
Recommend that the responsible Specialist Team is from the local specialist renal centre and liaise with other centres if necessary.
[no response]
Share PFD reports and learning with Regional Medical Directors and clinical colleagues via the Regulation 28 Working Group.

concern_responses.concern: There may be variation in how specialist renal hospitals engage with non-specialist hospitals that rely on their expertise, impacting collaborative efforts in patient care, and currently there is no clear guidance on how specialist and non-specialist teams should work together effectively to ensure consistent, high-quality care for these patients.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust
action_phrases: Received management guidelines from UHCW Renal Team and developed robust joint clinical guidelines for collaborative care.

responses.respondent: The Chief Executive Officer of University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: UHCW will now be the primary specialist transfer centre for all renal patients admitted to GEH regardless of parent specialist unit, with shared guidelines and SLA.
Share recommendations with the kidney care and transplant communities, contact patient associations, and share with Royal College of Physicians Patient Safety Committee.
Share recommendations with the kidney care and transplant communities, contact patient associations, and share with Royal College of Physicians Patient Safety Committee.
[no response]
Share PFD reports and learning with Regional Medical Directors and clinical colleagues via the Regulation 28 Working Group.

receiver: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council

concern_responses.concern: Communication with service users around moving accommodation needs to be managed carefully, as false assurances can undermine trust between the service user and the supporting team.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Introduce a visual flowchart of the accommodation process to be shared with individuals, care providers, and representatives from February 2025.

concern_responses.concern: Uncertainty regarding accommodation moves can be a potential stressor or trigger for self-harm for those with a diagnosis of Emotionally Unstable Personality Disorder, and this situation requires careful management and communication.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Include guidance in the weekly internal newsletter (week commencing 13th January 2025) for staff to reassure individuals at each stage and avoid stressful periods for moves.

concern_responses.concern: Those supporting Alison, including community mental health nurses, were unclear on the stage the process had reached, the specific steps of the process, and the likely timescales involved, which affected the type of support they could provide.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Create and share a visual flowchart of the accommodation process with all involved parties to clarify steps and timescales, starting February 2025.

concern_responses.concern: There was a lack of evidence of a specific approach or policy addressing how the process of moving accommodation can be clearly communicated to those supporting service users in the community.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Develop and implement a visual flowchart as a specific communication tool for the accommodation move process, to be introduced in February 2025.

concern_responses.concern: No internal review was carried out at Leicestershire County Council following Alison's death, and failure to conduct such reviews could lead to inadequate learning from deaths, creating a risk of further deaths.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Implement a new procedure for all Adult Social Care managers to conduct internal reviews after unexpected deaths, going live in January 2025.

concern_responses.concern: There is a real lack of specialist rehabilitation accommodation for women, particularly those assessed as low or medium risk of harm to others but high risk of self-harm, resulting in little or no effective system of rehabilitative provision for this cohort, with the situation reportedly worsening despite previous reviews and findings of gender disparity.

action_phrases: Implement new initiatives including the Women’s Justice Board and Women’s Policy Framework to renew focus on accommodation requirements for women in the criminal justice system.

concern_responses.concern: Probation officers responsible for finding accommodation and building release plans lack sufficient understanding of what accommodation is and is not available, as demonstrated by failures to realise that an Approved Premises might have been available and to act quickly when specialist placements fell through, indicating a training need.

action_phrases: Deliver Female AP briefings for all practitioners from September to emphasise availability and criteria for Approved Premises placements for women with complex needs.

concern_responses.concern: Steps to Recovery's systems for offering specialist accommodation have not always kept pace with their growth, resulting in unclear placement offers, conditions, and expectations, inadequate recording and structuring of decisions around offers and withdrawals, and the risk of withdrawing accommodation offers without first consulting the requesting organisation, all of which pose ongoing risks.

action_phrases: Implement a new ‘Offer/Acceptance’ document detailing placement offers and conditions, with written and verbal communication to all parties, and record all decisions in Lamplight, regularly audited by senior management.

receiver: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board

concern_responses.concern: When the ambulance service is under extreme pressure, individuals who have fallen at home can wait many hours on the floor before paramedics can attend.

responses.respondent: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: Continue to work as a multi-agency group to minimise EMAS response times in the short term.

concern_responses.concern: Falls are usually given a lower categorisation by the ambulance service because they are not considered life-threatening situations, leading to delayed response.

responses.respondent: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Long waits on the floor after a fall can increase the risk of pneumonia, pressure damage, and rhabdomyolysis.

responses.respondent: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: Seek to implement options that further mitigate the risk of a long lie following a fall for all Derby & Derbyshire residents.

concern_responses.concern: There is no local falls service or team operating out of hours, other than the ambulance service, to assess patients and assist them off the floor following a fall.

responses.respondent: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: Seek to accelerate the development and roll out of a falls prevention service available to all residents, including consideration of an injurious falls service, through NHS planning for 2025/26.

receiver: National Institute for Health & Care Excellence (NICE)

concern_responses.concern: Propranolol continues to be widely prescribed, often to young people reporting symptoms of anxiety, but there is an under-appreciation of the level of risk posed by elevated levels of propranolol medication.

responses.respondent: National Institute for Health & Care Excellence (NICE)
action_phrases: NICE will not be updating CG113 at this time following surveillance review and consultation with GP advisors.

concern_responses.concern: Evidence suggests that social ostracism is a recognised practice within student communities, with multiple cases observed and acknowledged by both students and staff, and this may be an issue more broadly for universities in the UK.

action_phrases: Work with experts and university welfare officials to convene a roundtable in early 2025 exploring social ostracism in more depth.

concern_responses.concern: Students appear to employ social ostracism as a means of 'self-policing' their community, often in response to allegations of serious misconduct, occurring in the absence of formal processes and without proper investigation or evidence.

action_phrases: Support OfS in introducing new regulatory requirements (condition E6) for handling harassment and sexual misconduct, effective August 2025, requiring formal policies and procedures.

concern_responses.concern: Social ostracism can have severe and lasting negative impacts on mental health, leading to feelings of isolation, shame, guilt, and worthlessness, all of which are recognised risk factors for suicide.

action_phrases: Provide £15 million in 2024/25 via OfS to support higher education providers in developing mental health and suicide prevention strategies.

concern_responses.concern: The prevalence of social ostracism may be linked to a lack of trust in formal channels for reporting serious concerns, as students may perceive these processes as ineffective, unfair, or biased, leading them to seek alternative means of addressing perceived wrongdoing.

action_phrases: Support OfS in requiring universities to publish and maintain clear policies and procedures for reporting and handling harassment and sexual misconduct from August 2025.

concern_responses.concern: There is concern that social ostracism has become normalised within student communities, with individuals viewing it as an expected and accepted response to certain allegations or behaviours, which hinders the development of healthy and supportive social environments.

action_phrases: Convene a roundtable in early 2025 to build shared knowledge and discuss appropriate responses to the normalisation of social ostracism in student communities.

concern_responses.concern: The deceased left the hospital on 19 July before being clinically assessed due to waiting times.

action_phrases: Implemented the NHSE Acuity Tool from 25th November 2024 to ensure all ED patients receive an initial, primary assessment on arrival.

concern_responses.concern: There was no consideration of whether secondary investigations, such as a CT scan, could be undertaken during the waiting time.

action_phrases: Secondary investigations (such as a CT scan) will be considered and frontloaded for patients meeting NICE criteria for CT scan in head injury whilst awaiting clinical review.

concern_responses.concern: No evidence was provided that the deceased’s capacity to decide to leave the hospital was assessed, despite a history of suspected head injury.

action_phrases: New SOP requires nursing and clinical staff to assess mental capacity for patients stating they want to leave and escalate concerns appropriately.

concern_responses.concern: It was unclear what the new standard operating procedure for patients leaving the hospital before clinical assessment will include.

action_phrases: Drafted a Standard Operating Procedure for patients leaving ED before assessment, with estimated approval date of 6th February 2025, to be shared with all urgent and emergency care areas.

receiver: President Royal, Royal College of General Practitioners
President of the Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
President of the Royal College of Surgeons
President of the Royal College of Radiologists

concern_responses.concern: Neither the original GP, the reviewing surgical SHO or surgical registrar considered that Lacey had appendicitis, and the consultant surgeon reviewing Lacey on 24th could not reach a diagnosis despite recognising she was ill.

action_phrases: Shared the report with Specialty Advisory Committee Chairs for consideration during upcoming curricula reviews.
Remain committed to supporting ongoing educational resources for both the GP Curriculum and Continuing Professional Development in this area.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: Will share information and suggestions for local improvement from the report with paediatric members via the patient safety portal.
Advocate prompt assessment by experienced clinicians including expert surgeons and radiologists.

concern_responses.concern: Retrocaecal appendicitis presentation is not a rare presentation of either acute appendicitis or generalised abdominal pain, contrary to the slant of available literature.

action_phrases: Reviewing the content of CCRISP and Clinical Skills in Emergency Surgery courses to consider explicit reference to retrocaecal appendicitis.
Highlight that NICE CKS guidance used by GPs specifically mentions the presentation of retrocaecal appendicitis.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: Will ensure signposting to the Best Practice Pathway Resource for paediatric acute abdominal pain and appendicectomy.
Advocate using similar imaging strategies for retrocaecal appendicitis as for general appendicitis.

concern_responses.concern: The availability and use of bedside/departmental ultrasound scanning in abdominal pain (e.g. in the young), especially out of hours, is a concern.

action_phrases: Recommend seeking advice from the Royal College of Radiologists regarding out of hours paediatric radiology service provision.
State that bedside ultrasound scanning is not routinely available in general practice and would require policy change, investment, and training development.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: [no response]
Advocate ongoing clinical evaluation and repeating ultrasound at a short interval if initial imaging is equivocal.

concern_responses.concern: There is a concern regarding the training of doctors in considering appendicitis as a possible differential diagnosis to generalised abdominal pain.

action_phrases: Shared the report with Specialty Advisory Committee Chairs for consideration during upcoming curricula reviews.
Support General Practitioners in undertaking telephone consultation and triage skills courses including consideration of appendicitis as a differential diagnosis.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: Will share anonymised information from the report for discussion with the RCPCH Clinical Quality in Practice Committee.
Advocate prompt assessment by experienced clinicians including expert surgeons and radiologists.

concern_responses.concern: Bottles of sevoflurane, whether unopened or partially used after theatre, are not robustly monitored, allowing for the possibility that a bottle could be removed from Cannock Chase Hospital without detection by the auditing system.

action_phrases: Introduce daily stock counts of full bottles, part bottles and empty bottles of sevoflurane to ensure all are accounted for.
Continue to explore and support improvements in the controlled, authorised and auditable access to medicines.

concern_responses.concern: The trust was unable to confirm or refute that the bottle of sevoflurane found at the deceased’s home address originated from Cannock Chase Hospital.

action_phrases: [no response]
Consider the hospital’s response and any actions arising from this in due course.

receiver: Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents

concern_responses.concern: There is insufficient awareness among road users of the phenomenon of aquaplaning and the need to reduce speed when surface water is present, as well as basic knowledge about braking and steering in such situations.

action_phrases: Continue to work with stakeholders to amplify road safety messages and encourage inclusion of aquaplaning where appropriate.
Launch and promote a winter driving e-learning course through www.safedrivingforlife.info in November 2023.

responses.respondent: Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents
action_phrases: Create and share digital education materials on aquaplaning awareness through social media and website in Q4 2024.

concern_responses.concern: The Highway Code does not currently provide information or guidance on aquaplaning, despite its relevance to road safety.

action_phrases: Consider including advice on aquaplaning at the next major revision of the Highway Code during the usual consultation process.
[no response]

responses.respondent: Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents
action_phrases: Engage with the Department for Transport and DVSA regarding coroner's findings on aquaplaning guidance in Q4 2024.

receiver: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care

concern_responses.concern: National targets for ambulance response times, specifically for Category 3 999 calls, are not being adhered to, with actual response times significantly exceeding the target.

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care
action_phrases: Government will publish a 10-Year Health Plan in Spring 2025 to set out radical reforms for the NHS, including ambulance response times.

concern_responses.concern: The current wording of some of the script used by Call Handlers under NHS Pathways may create a misleading impression that an ambulance has been dispatched when this is not the case, potentially deterring callers from seeking alternative help.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: There is potential under the NHS Pathways paradigm for an ambulance response to be cancelled without first discussing this with the person who requested the ambulance.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care
action_phrases: [no response]

receiver: Operations Director, Tenancy and Homeowner Services, London Borough of Hackney

concern_responses.concern: Residents at [REDACTED] have been climbing onto their balconies to clear blocked drainpipes, which carries a clear risk of falls.

responses.respondent: Operations Director, Tenancy and Homeowner Services, London Borough of Hackney
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The leaseholder of [REDACTED] was not aware of any work being undertaken to the guttering or drainpipes to the block following Ms McGreevy’s death.

responses.respondent: Operations Director, Tenancy and Homeowner Services, London Borough of Hackney
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: In the absence of remedial works, the practice of residents unblocking pipes themselves is likely to continue.

responses.respondent: Operations Director, Tenancy and Homeowner Services, London Borough of Hackney
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The pedestrian crossing area across Jersey Road on the A4 Great West Road lacks pedestrian traffic lights, a demand button, and sound signals, making it difficult for pedestrians to judge when it is safe to cross.

action_phrases: TfL will implement a new pedestrian crossing design with a push button unit, rotating cone, and green person signal at the A4/Jersey Road junction.
LBH will work with TfL to ensure the new signal-controlled crossing design for pedestrians and cyclists is technically sound and aligns with local users' needs.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: At no point during the normal use of the traffic light controlled junction does traffic cease to flow at the marked crossing area, increasing the risk for pedestrians attempting to cross.

action_phrases: TfL will design the new pedestrian crossing to hold traffic on the A4, allowing pedestrians time to cross safely.
LBH will review and consult on TfL's new crossing design to ensure it addresses pedestrian safety at the junction.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: There have been other accidents involving pedestrians and moving vehicles at this pedestrian crossing in the past.

action_phrases: TfL has undertaken a thorough review of historic collision data and will consider further changes to the highway layout to reduce collision risk.
LBH will continue to work with TfL and stakeholders to secure priority implementation of safety measures at the crossing.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: The implementation of existing plans by TFL to re-design this pedestrian crossing to improve pedestrian safety may not take place before the end of 2026 and is subject to the consent of the DFT and LBH, the outcome of any public consultation, and funding considerations.

action_phrases: TfL aims to implement the proposed improvement works within three years, subject to public engagement, design, and funding.
LBH will work with TfL to facilitate and consult on the new crossing design, aiming for construction in 2026-27.
DFT confirms no consent or approval is required from the Department for TfL to implement the crossing redesign.

concern_responses.concern: There is no certainty that the redesign plans for the pedestrian crossing in question will be implemented.

action_phrases: TfL will progress through scheme governance stages and provide updates on implementation timings and post-implementation monitoring.
LBH will continue to work with TfL and stakeholders to secure priority implementation of the crossing redesign.
DFT confirms implementation of the crossing redesign is within TfL and LBH's remit, not subject to DFT approval.

receiver: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence

concern_responses.concern: There is no national guidance to assist clinicians in primary care in assessing whether they should consider prolonging the course of anti-coagulation prescribed in secondary care to reduce the ongoing risk of elderly immobile patients developing a fatal DVT in the community.

responses.respondent: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence
action_phrases: We will review our guidance on stopping and starting VTE prophylaxis to see if an update is warranted.

concern_responses.concern: Maintaining ketamine's classification as a class B drug is likely to encourage people to use it under the false impression that it is safer than class A drugs.

action_phrases: Commission the ACMD to conduct an updated harms assessment of ketamine as part of the forthcoming three-year work programme commission cycle.

concern_responses.concern: Ketamine use causes significant long-term, life-changing health problems, including urological and liver damage, which can be fatal.

action_phrases: Commission the ACMD to conduct an updated harms assessment of ketamine as part of the forthcoming three-year work programme commission cycle.

concern_responses.concern: There is a significant increase in illicit ketamine use, leading to a rise in potentially fatal health problems, and users rarely understand the extent of these risks until after harm has occurred.

action_phrases: Commission the ACMD to conduct an updated harms assessment of ketamine as part of the forthcoming three-year work programme commission cycle.

receiver: Secretary of State for Housing, Communities, and Local Government

concern_responses.concern: There is a lack of accommodation available to the Probation Service in which prisoners released from custody may properly be placed, including both Approved Premises (the responsibility of the MoJ) and more generally through the local authority to avoid homelessness.

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Housing, Communities, and Local Government
action_phrases: Continue to work closely with MoJ to identify and implement what is needed to ensure all prison leavers are able to access accommodation.
Expand Community Accommodation Service (CAS) provision, including increasing CAS2 capacity towards 1350 spaces and expanding CAS3 to support more people at risk of homelessness each year.

concern_responses.concern: As a consequence of the lack of suitable accommodation, some prisoners are released and become effectively homeless (with increased difficulties in supervision) while others are accommodated at unsuitable premises.

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Housing, Communities, and Local Government
action_phrases: Work with local authorities to promote a partnership approach to the statutory referral mechanism and improve quality of information sharing to promote better assessments.

Minister of State for Prisons, Probation and Reducing Reoffending will lead on reducing the number of people leaving prison homeless and ensuring appropriate accommodation for those with higher support needs.

receiver: The Chief Executive Officer of the Coventry and Warwickshire Partnership Trust

concern_responses.concern: Section 17 leave conditions may not always be thoroughly reviewed or clarified before a service user is signed out for leave, leading to unaddressed discrepancies that may impact the safety and appropriateness of unescorted leave.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive Officer of the Coventry and Warwickshire Partnership Trust
action_phrases: Reviewed and updated Section 17 Leave Policy with cross-directorate input and implemented toolkit with step-by-step guidance, checklists, and staff training materials.

concern_responses.concern: There may be a lack of accessible or reliable means for service users on unescorted leave to contact the facility if they encounter difficulties, impacting their ability to seek support or assistance when needed.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive Officer of the Coventry and Warwickshire Partnership Trust
action_phrases: Developed and implemented a 'contact card' with key phone numbers for patients accessing leave, and exploring pre-arranged check-ins by the ward team.

concern_responses.concern: There may be limitations in the reporting system’s ability to identify and address substantive issues that directly impact patient safety, risking that critical concerns are overlooked and valuable insights for preventing future incidents are missed.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive Officer of the Coventry and Warwickshire Partnership Trust
action_phrases: Transitioned from Serious Incident Framework to Patient Safety Incident Response Framework (PSIRF), developed PSIRF Plan and Policy, and engaged external consultancy for staff training and assurance.

concern_responses.concern: There is a delay in information about what has been prescribed to an individual being sent to the GP surgery by voluntary and NHS organisations.

action_phrases: Implement national adoption of interoperable medicine standards (IMS) to underpin transfer of medication information at hospital admission and discharge.
[no response]

receiver: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council

concern_responses.concern: Carers employed by A&B Healthcare sometimes spent as little as 8 to 15 minutes with Ms Townend, which was not adequate to complete required tasks, document keeping, and care, including attention to Early Warning Signs.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]
CQC will undertake an unannounced assessment of the service which will include staff having adequate time to meet people’s needs.

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not escalate any concerns when Ms Townend was not eating, despite her comorbidities and risk of infection making nutrition very important.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]
CQC will undertake an unannounced assessment of the service which will include nutrition and hydration and how staff identify people’s changing needs and escalate concerns.

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not escalate any concerns when Ms Townend was unwell with sickness, even though there were several occasions when she had been sick.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]
CQC will undertake an unannounced assessment of the service which will include how people are supported to live healthier lives and how the provider will monitor peoples care.

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not accurately record concerns regarding Early Warning Signs (EWS) or escalate when they were present, with EWS always recorded as no concerns even when signs were present.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]
CQC will undertake an unannounced assessment of the service which will include recording keeping, governance processes and oversight of people’s care.

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not follow up with Ms Townend after she indicated she was seeking GP support for feeling unwell, as recorded in the Observation Log, and proceeding carers did not enquire whether this had been done.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]
CQC will undertake an unannounced assessment of the service which will include governance processes and oversight of people’s care.

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not escalate concerns when Ms Townend, though deemed to have capacity, made unwise decisions to refuse personal care, decline food, and decline medical intervention, resulting in her sitting in her own faeces and becoming weak, and it was not considered whether she needed reassessment regarding her capacity.

action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Since November 2023, ERYC ASCH has implemented new safeguarding forms and a new service model to improve recording, sharing outcomes, and person-centred safeguarding enquiries.

CQC will undertake an unannounced assessment of the service which will include safeguarding and decision making, and has requested immediate assurances from the provider regarding safeguarding processes.

receiver: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council

concern_responses.concern: The quality of the review following referrals from Yorkshire Ambulance Service and Hull Royal Infirmary to Adults Safeguarding was lacking.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Implemented a new service and practice model for safeguarding adults, including new forms and processes to improve review quality since November 2023.

concern_responses.concern: The Safeguarding Adult Review did not appropriately probe the responses received from the care company and the Community Nurses.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Addressed practice issues with the individual practitioner and disseminated lessons learned within the team to improve future probing of responses.

concern_responses.concern: The procedure adopted for the review did not record how the responses had been obtained, and the family's input was not recorded.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Launched new forms in November 2023 requiring practitioners to record methodology and include the voice of the person and their family in the enquiry record.

concern_responses.concern: The review process was conducted hastily and not to appropriate standards that would have been of any benefit.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Implemented a training programme and practice workshops to ensure practitioners understand expectations and standards for conducting safeguarding reviews.

concern_responses.concern: The outcomes of the review and recommendations were not provided to the subjects of the review.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Implemented new paperwork requiring workers to state who they have shared outcomes and recommendations with, enabling monitoring and audit of this process.

concern_responses.concern: There was a lack of professional curiosity and the full review process was not followed or documented properly.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Rolled out training and learning with new forms to refresh practitioners' understanding and encourage professional curiosity in safeguarding enquiries.

concern_responses.concern: The procedure for conducting Safeguarding reviews needs to be looked at to avoid any impact on anyone else.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Undertook a full review and remodel of the safeguarding adults service since early 2023 to improve procedures and outcomes.

concern_responses.concern: No evidence was presented as to whether the safeguarding team at Huddersfield New College was aware of Mr Grierson discontinuing his referral and treatment from CAMHS and his intention to discharge himself from Recovery Steps.

action_phrases: [no response]
[no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: No information concerning Mr Grierson's current mental health issues was provided to Huddersfield New College within a mitigation statement by him.

action_phrases: [no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: The latest communication concerning Mr Grierson's mental health provided by CAMHS to the college was dated October 2023, and communication between the college and CAMHS and Recovery Steps was not maintained to enable the college's awareness of Mr Grierson's current mental health in April 2024 and his decisions to remove external support.

action_phrases: [no response]
[no response]
[no response]

receiver: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council

concern_responses.concern: The narrow width of the path at the location of Mrs Friedhoff’s accident (about 2 metres, reducing to 1.6 metres before the accident site) is significantly less than the national guidance of 3.5 metres for such paths, increasing the risk of accidents between pedestrians and cyclists.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Undertake surveying of pedestrian and cycle use in the Iffley lock area in spring/summer 2025 to quantify volumes, types, and speeds.

concern_responses.concern: The path is a shared space that is heavily used by both pedestrians and cyclists, with some cyclists travelling at significant speed in close proximity to pedestrians, creating an obvious accident risk.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Undertake surveying of pedestrian and cycle use in the Iffley lock area in spring/summer 2025 to quantify volumes, types, and speeds.

concern_responses.concern: The upgraded surface of the path in recent years has likely encouraged greater use by cyclists and enabled them to cycle faster, increasing the risk to pedestrians.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Undertake surveying of pedestrian and cycle use in the Iffley lock area in spring/summer 2025 to quantify volumes, types, and speeds.

concern_responses.concern: Despite signage and the Environment Agency not permitting cyclists to cycle through locks, enforcement is difficult and cyclists continue to use the path, particularly at speed, posing a risk to pedestrians.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Organise with partners and user groups a series of promotional events from spring 2025 to highlight safe and responsible use of the towpath.

concern_responses.concern: There is a lack of clear signage reminding users, particularly cyclists, of the need to take care and slow down around pedestrians.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Undertake an audit of signage in winter/early 2025 and implement any appropriate additional signage by summer 2025.

concern_responses.concern: Potential mitigating measures such as a communications package with public consultation, stronger enforcement, gates or similar to slow cyclists, segregation lines (which are problematic due to the narrow width), and reconfiguring the path to create separate routes for pedestrians and cyclists have not yet been fully explored or implemented.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Engage with local councillors and key stakeholders in early 2025 to develop and implement the above measures.

receiver: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, Department of Health and Social Care

concern_responses.concern: There is a chronic shortage of mental health beds, both in London and nationally, resulting in patients like Mr Singh being unable to return to a mental health ward after discharge from a medical ward.

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, Department of Health and Social Care
action_phrases: Publish statutory guidance on Discharge from mental health inpatient settings in January 2024 to support safe and timely discharge decisions.
Invest a further £42 million recurrently from 2024/25 for all Integrated Care Boards to recommission inpatient care in line with local models.

receiver: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

concern_responses.concern: Mrs Tromans' Waterlow score was underestimated in the Emergency Department, failing to identify her as at very high risk of pressure sores, and she spent almost 18 hours on a trolley without pressure area care.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Tissue Viability team and ED Matrons have implemented a project to reduce pressure ulcers in ED, including targeted staff training, new pressure-relieving trolley mattresses, updated Waterlow score documentation, and regular audits.

concern_responses.concern: The repositioning schedule requiring repositioning at no greater intervals of four hours was not adhered to on 22 occasions, resulting in Mrs Tromans being left in the same position for up to 14 hours.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Weekly audit of repositioning practices in AMU with real-time feedback, staff education events, and implementation of the Response Assessment Tool to monitor compliance.

concern_responses.concern: The paper version of the wound care plan on East Ground B ward, intended for detailed monitoring and treatment of pressure sores, was not completed at any stage.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Updated Wound Assessment Chart is now available and staff are being trained in its use, with quarterly audits to monitor documentation and adherence.

concern_responses.concern: The Matron's investigation into gaps in care did not seek to establish why they had occurred, raising concerns about the quality and efficacy of the Trust's post-death investigations.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Investigation process will be revised to include individual staff statements and findings embedded into roundtable reports, with learning disseminated to clinical teams.
